messageBody:
Two thoughts on Jerome and computer typing in quickscript:

I have only recently begun to read Shavian and Quickscript. I enjoy
some of the advantages of both. Read's extension of abreviations and
abreviated words in Quickscript seem wonderful. However, I find the
small "curleys" in the type version of Jerome hard on my eyes.

I really appreciate the hard work done on Jerome, but believe
Quickscript readers could also do with a font that does not look like
penmanship.

From reading Read's booklet on Quickscript, it appears that most of
the half letter and joinings were instituted to make writing with a
pen easier, not reading easier. Much like script penmanship, I
believe that most of them detract from the readability of the text
when the text is in an electronic version. (BTW, I gave up on script
writing in the seventh grade about 36 years ago and have been
printing ever since so that my handwriting can be easily read. I use
the computer to write letters for the same reason.)

I can not imagine wanting to read a font on the computer which
attempts to mimic script... I know they exist, but to prefer this
for everyday reading! No thanks.

I have been thinking along two lines.

First, is there already a version of Quickscript True Type font which
looks more like the Junior Quickscript of Read's manual? If not, I
may invest a little time and come up with one. I think it could
improve readability in the way that ghoti and lionspaw are very
readable Shavian scripts.

Second, is there a way to program the keyboard interface to scan for
combination letters other than shift, ctl and alt? I recently worked
on a 7 key keyboard that used "chord fingerings" for letters. Chord
fingerings seem like a natural for phonetic languages like
Quickscript. It is easy enough to remember cap T for "theater" but
cap Y for "oil"?? Would it not be nice to just press the o and i
keys? The computer would run the following algorhythm when you
pressed the o key... hmmm... o key, must be an o, ... no the i key is
also pressed must be an "oil" now wait for the next letter press.

I have not worked the keyboard interface to see if this kind of chord
keying could be instituted within the present operating systems or
not. Any computer programmmers with feedback?

Rick


--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@c...> wrote:
> I have attached an example of Junior and Senior Quikscript to this
> post. I had to use an attachment because I got sick of Windows
crashing
> all the time and switched to using Linux for my operating system.
I am
> running Windows 98 in a window under Linux. I haven't figured out
how
> to get Jerome into the Linux side of my computer yet. (I'm not even
> sure its possible since it is a truetype font.)
>
> Paige Gabhart
